bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William E. Deeks, March 21, 1925

div1.p: [Carter] comments on Deeks' monograph on malaria, and he suggests changes.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William E. Deeks, March 21, 1925
div1.opener:
Miscl
Deeks
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
March 21, 1925.
Dear Doctor Deeks:
div1.p:
I received your letter of the 19th. instant with the monograph
on Malaria. Thank you for both.

Of the latter I have no criticism to make. The text is good:
clear and sufficiently full without being verbose: the illustrations
well selected: clear and artistically beautiful: Some, of course,
are diagramatic (as in Plates B and C), but this is intentional and as
you give drawings from the slides also this simply makes for clear-
ness.

If I were writing this myself, I would consider rewriting the
two Paragraphs on Page 28, beginning “Efforts therefore” and “In
villages,” so as to show that some of the measures therein recom-
mended are for the control of mosquitoes as a pest and not for Ano-
pheles. To get rid of water in artificial containers: old cans etc.
is a legitimate means of controlling mosquitoes other than Anopheles
(practically C. fatigans (quinquefasciatus) and Stegomyia), but as
advocated here it implies that it is desireable as a measure to con-
trol malaria--that Anopheles of sanitary importance breed in such
collections of water--and this scientifically incorrect and I think you
would not want an error of this kind in this brochure. If you recall,
LePrince and Griffitts agreed with me in this.

Also a 16 mesh wire gauze of wire of any guage we have found on the
market will exclude Anopheles, but for Stegomyia No. 18 of same guage is
required and while the latter may be recommended for comfort's sake--to
keep out Stegomyia also--I think the reason for using it should be given.
Of course, the finer the mesh the less breeze admitted--a matter of some
importance in the Tropics--and the more apt is the screen to be blown in in
squalls.

I am sending this by special delivery in order that it may reach you
in time to wish you a pleasant and satisfactory trip.

With very best remembrances to yourself, Mrs. Deeks and your small
daughter, as well as such of our friends among your force as you may
chance to see, in all of which Laura joins, I remain
